title: Nothing to fear: EU trade benefits are 'largely imaginary', says think tank
text: GETTY Civitas said British exports outside the EU have been growing quicker The growth of goods exports of the UK to 11 long-standing members of the EU over these 43 years are barely distinguishable from those of 14 countries exporting under WTO rules, and they, of course, have not incurred any of the costs of EU membership It's Quite OK to Walk Away report It states: "The growth of goods exports of the UK to 11 long-standing members of the EU over these 43 years are barely distinguishable from those of 14 countries exporting under WTO rules, and they, of course, have not incurred any of the costs of EU membership. "The evidence shows that the disadvantages of non membership of the EU and single market have been vastly exaggerated and that the supposed benefits of membership, whether for exports of goods and services, for productivity, for world-wide trade, or for employment, are largely imaginary." The report backs Prime Minister T heresa May 's claim that no deal with the EU is better than a bad deal, arguing it is an "acceptable option and not one that has to be feared". GETTY The report backs Theresa May's claim that no deal with the EU is better than a bad deal Major economies with EU free trade agreements have seen trade rocket by an average of 135 per cent to core single market members since 1993 but UK export growth to the same countries was just 25 per cent, the report found. The study found no evidence that single market membership had a positive impact on UK national income and claimed the EU's international trade agreements have been of little benefit to Britain, covering just 6.1 per cent of goods exports and 1.8 per cent of services. Author Michael Burrage said: "The evidence shows that the disadvantages of non-membership of the EU and single market have been vastly exaggerated and that the supposed benefits of membership, whether for exports of goods and services, for productivity, for world-wide trade, or for employment, are largely imaginary. Theresa May's most powerful quotes Fri, March 10, 2017
